awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Time-of-Flight(MALDI TOF) Mass Spectrometer for of Research and Research Training at CSULA
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation Program. Professor Yong Ba from California State University Los Angeles and colleagues Jamil Momand, Edith Porter, Yixian Wang and Cecilia Zurita-Lopez are acquiring a matrix-assisted laser desorption / ionization time-of-flight mass spectrometer (MALDI-TOF-MS) equipped with a photodiode array. In general, mass spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species in complex samples. MALDI TOF combines gentle ionization (ideal for producing intact ions of peptides, proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, synthetic polymers, and other similarly sized species) with a detection mode that offers an excellent balance between sensitivity and accuracy across a wide range of samples. The acquisition strengthens the research infrastructure at the university and within the regional. The instrument broadens participation by giving hands-on access to a diverse student population. The instrument is also used in outreach activities.

The award is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It especially impacts studies correlating molecular structure, orientation and dynamics.   Researchers use the MALDI-TOF-MS to study interactions of a mucoadhesive co-polymer colloidal gel systems and in identifying in vivo substrates and binding partners for the protein arginine methyltransferase 7 (PRMT7) in mammalian cells. The mass spectrometer is used for studying cell disruption mechanisms that may be operational in Parkinson's disease and for studying antifreeze proteins. The instrument also serves researchers identifying proteins associated with t-Darpp AKT activation proteins, in which t-Darpp is a truncated isoform of dopamine-regulated phosphoprotein having an elongated monomer that binds calcium and is phosphorylated by cyclin-dependent enzyme kinases. Finally, the instrument is used by researchers investigating antimicrobial peptides.  Overall, the instrument acquisition may benefit the National health and welfare as well as supporting education and diversity.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.inst_name: California State L A University Auxiliary Services Inc.
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: CAL STATE LA UNIVERSITY AUXILIARY SERVICES INC

por.por_cntn:
A MALDI-TOF (Matrix-Assisted Laser Desorption/Ionization Time-of-Flight) Mass Spectrometry was awarded to California State University, Los Angeles (Cal State LA) by the NSF MRI program. MALDI TOF spectrometer is one of the most useful chemical and biological sciences instruments to identify and quantify natural, engineered, and artificially modified compounds including small and large proteins and synthesized molecules constructed from repeating subunits also called polymers. The MALDI TOF spectrometer is critical for identifying proteins, mapping protein modifications, and confirming the synthesis of polymers. The acquired new MALDI TOF spectrometer is pivotal for sustained research and research training at Cal State LA. We have used the instrument for research and research training of our undergraduates and graduate students, and for laboratory teaching in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry and in the Department of Biological Sciences at Cal State LA. This instrument has contributed to analyzing the molecular weights in a broad range of research including the study of viscous and elastic  properties of biomedical hydrogel systems,  rapid identification of  in vivo substrates and binding partners for enzymes in mammalian cells, study on cell disruption mechanism in Parkinson’s disease by comprehensive instrumental techniques to analyze molecules that play a role in the development of Parkinson disease, namely alpha-synuclein (α-Syn) aggregates, and, antifreeze function and mechanism of chemically modified antifreeze proteins, identification of proteins that associate with t-Darpp AKT activation protein, natural protein-based antibiotics made by cells lining the respiratory tract known as antimicrobial peptides, and studying the action of antimicrobial peptides on the formation of biofilms, masses of bacteria enwrapped in a gluey substance, by the bacterium Pseudomonas aeruginosa. This instrument has also been used for teaching and research training through teaching laboratory experiments including CHEM 4520: Advanced Instrumental Analysis Course: Separation and Mass Spectrometry to identify large proteins, CHEM 4321: Biochemistry Lab II, and MICR 4600: Theoretical and Applied Immunology (to identify the antimicrobial protein lysozyme in saliva). This MALDI TOF instrument has a significant impact on the education, research training and research of ~1400 BS undergraduate majors and ~70 MS graduate majors in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, and in the Department of Biological Sciences.   

Cal State LA is a research-intensive primarily undergraduate institution with strong MS programs and an unparalleled record in training minority science and engineering students in California, home to the largest concentration of minority populations in the nation. The proportion of underrepresented minoritized students exceeds 62.8% of the 27,681 total enrollment and women make up 58.2% of the University’s student population. Through NSF- and NIH-funded programs, Cal State LA has been able to engage a large number of students in research, resulting in a strong and positive impact on their retention, graduation rates, and pursuit of advanced degrees. The MALDI TOF spectrometer has become a valuable addition to the research infrastructure at Cal State LA, allowing us to continue to conduct research, offering advanced training in this technique to our students, and exposing many more students to this technology in the classroom. 

 


Last Modified: 12/12/2022
Modified by: Yong Ba

This MALDI TOF instrument has a significant impact on the education, research training and research of ~1400 BS undergraduate majors and ~70 MS graduate majors in the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, and in the Department of Biological Sciences.
